title: The Resurrection

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of oil on canvas.

artist_display:
Francesco Buoneri, called Cecco del Caravaggio 
Italian, 1588/90–after 1620
description:
Francesco Buoneri was one of the closest followers of Caravaggio, the groundbreaking and influential painter of the Italian Baroque period. Buoneri may have assisted and modeled for Caravaggio during the elder painter’s last years in Rome, a personal connection suggested by his contemporary nickname, Cecco (a diminutive of Francesco) del Carravaggio. The Resurrection exaggerates the bold contrast of light and dark and the realistic treatment of sacred figures that were hallmarks of Caravaggio’s revolutionary style.

The only documented painting by Buoneri, this work was commissioned in 1619 by the Tuscan ambassador to Rome, Piero Guicciardini, for his family’s chapel in Florence. For reasons lost to history, the painting was rejected, a not uncommon event in Rome’s rapidly evolving art scene. It was eventually sold to another important collector, Cardinal Scipione Borghese.
credit_line: Charles H. and Mary F. S. Worcester Collection
publication_history:
Mahonri Sharp Young, "Letter from U.S.A.: The Ruin of Painting,” Apollo 95, no. 117 (1972):61.

Arnauld Brejon de Lavergnée and Jean-Pierre Cuzin, I Caravaggeschi Francesi, exh. cat. (Rome : De Luca, 1973), 24-25.

Maurizio Marini, Io Michelangelo da Caravaggio (Rome: S tudio B di Bestetti e Bozzi, 1974), 476.

Luisa Vertova, ed., Caravaggism in Europe vol. 1, 2nd ed. (Torino: Umberto Allemandi, 1989), plates 448-49.

Gino Corti, “Il ‘Registro de’ mandate’ dell’ambasciatore granducale Pietro Guicciardini e la committenza artistica fiorentina a Roma nel secondo decennio del Seicento,” in Paragone 473, no. 16 (1989): 130-32.

Gianni Papi, “Pedro Nuñez del Valle e Cecco del Caravaggio (e un apostilla per Francesco Buoneri)," Arte Cristiana 79, no. 742 (1991): 39, 46-48, 49 (ill.)

Anna Ottani Cavina, "Un Dipinto di Cecco del Caravaggio," in Studi di Storia dell’Arte in Onore di Mina Gregori (Milan: Silvana, 1994), 159 fig. 2, 160.

Giovanna Capitelli and Caterina Volpi, Caravaggio e il Caravaggismo (Rome: Bagatto Libri, 1995), 191-94.

Jane Turner, ed., The Dictionary of Art vol. 5 (New York: Grove, 1996), 702.

Richard Ward, “Those Who Came Before: Caravaggio and His Principal Italian Followers,” in Sinners and Saints: Darkness and Light; Caravaggio and His Dutch and Flemish Followers, exh. cat. (Raleigh, N.C.: North Carolina Museum of Art, 1997), 30 fig. 19, n.61-63.

Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio e i suoi primi seguaci, exh. cat. (Ente capitale europea della cultura "Salonicco '97", 1997) 

Sandro Corradini, “Un antico inventario della quadreria del Cardinale Borghese,” inBernini Scultore: La Nascita del Barocco in Casa Borghese, exh. cat., eds. Anna Colvina and Sebastian Schütze (Rome: Edizioni de Luca, 1998), 499, 452. 

Gianni Papi, Cecco del Caravaggio (Soncino Cremona: Edizioni dei Soncino, 2001), 8, 13, 19, 23, 28-30, 32, 44, 46, 51-52, 75 plate 19, 132-35 no. 16.

Beverly Louis Brown, ed., The Genius of Rome: 1592-1623, exh. cat. (London : Royal Academy of Arts, 2001), 6 under cat. 27.

Silvia Danesi Squarzina, Caravaggio e i Giustiniani : toccar con mano una collezione del Seicento, exh. cat. (Milan: Electa, 2001), 302.

Martina Sitt, Pieter Lastman: In Rembrandts Schatten?, exh. cat. (Hamburg : Hamburger Kunsthalle ; München : Hirmer, 2006), 144 under ca.t 23.

Michael Fried, “Notes Toward a Caravaggisti Pictoral Poetics” Caravaggio and His Followers in Rome, exh. cat. (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2012), 119, fig. 48. 

Gianni Papi, "Some Reflections and Revisions on Caravaggio, His Method, and His 'Schola,’ in Caravaggio and His Legacy, exh. cat. (Los Angeles: Los Angeles County Museum of Art; Munich: DelMonico Books/Prestel, 2012), 22 fig. 7, 23.

Gianni Papi, Cecco del Caracaggio: L’allievo modello, exh. cat. (Milan: Skira; Bergamo: Accademia Carrara, 2023), 170-173 (ill.), 224 (detail), 244.
exhibition_history:
Cleveland Museum of Art, Caravaggio and His Followers, Oct. 27, 1971-Jan. 2, 1972. 

Ottawa, National Gallery of Canada, June 17- Sep. 11, 2011, Caravaggio and His Followers in Rome, fig. 48; Fort Worth, Kimball Art Museum, Oct. 9, 2011-Jan. 8,  2012.
provenance_text: Commissioned by Piero Guicciardini, Rome, 1619 [according to mandates relating to payments for the decoration of the family chapel in Santa Felicita in Florence, published in Corti 1989 p. 130]; rejected upon completion and sold in Rome [this and the following according to the Oct. 18, 1620 entry of chapel expense account, cited in published in Corti 1989 p. 137, “…et sono per essermi accollato la terza tavola già fatta per mano di Francesco del Caravaggio et dàtola via, non havendo hauto sodisfatione d’essa.” See also Papi 2001.]. Cardinal Scipione Borghese, Rome, about 1620 [Borghese inventory, published in Corradini 1998]. Giorgio Sangiorgi (1886-1965), Rome [this and the following according to the Brummer Gallery inventory cards, Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York]; sold to the Brummer Gallery, New York, Aug. 19, 1931 as by Horatio Gentileschi for $2,400; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, Oct. 29, 1934 as by Horatio Gentileschi.
